thread.title: California enjoys ‘flower-geddon’ as nor’easter pounds East Coast | New York Post
thread.title_full: California enjoys ‘flower-geddon’ as nor’easter pounds East Coast | New York Post

author: Chris Perez
title: California enjoys ‘flower-geddon’ as nor’easter pounds East Coast | New York Post
text:
Wonder what Sam's perspective on the super bloom is 👁👁. #superbloom #poppies #flowers . . . #lakeelsinore #bloom #california #love #52hikechallenge2017 #roadtrip #explore #adventure #travel #discover #destination #outdoors #nature #naturelovers #wilderness #wildernessculture #wanderer #wanderlust #expandyourplayground #rei1440project #mountains #dog 
A post shared by Linda🤖-Sam🐶-Dewey🐕 (@__nuggetron__) on Mar 12, 2017 at 9:58pm PDT 
As if New Yorkers didn’t have enough reasons to hate Californians.
While residents in the Big Apple were hunkering down for Tuesday’s blizzard that never was , people in Southern California experienced a super bloom of wildflowers over the weekend — dubbed “flower-geddon.”
The region’s typically-barren desert landscape has transformed into a colorful oasis, filled with vibrant fields of white dune evening primroses, orange poppies and purple sand verbena as far as the eye can see.
The assortment of wildflowers — along with the vast amounts of greenery — has made Anza-Borrego Desert State Park a sight to behold over the past few days, with countless people sharing pictures of the super bloom on social media.
“What’s happened in the last four or five days is extraordinary,” Kathy DeMunck, an assistant manager at the park’s nature center, told National Geographic. 
“We really haven’t had this kind of a bloom since 2005,” she said. “The desert has really come alive.”
A “super bloom” is a term used to describe an explosion of wildflowers that normally exceeds typical spring blooms.
The rare event — which is being referred to by park rangers as “flower-geddon” — is also reportedly occurring in Diamond Valley Lake, in addition to Anza-Borrego state park.
“This kind of huge bloom happens maybe once a decade,” Jim Dice, research manager at the Anza-Borrego Desert Research Center, told Wired. 
Anza Borrego is expected to explode with wildflowers during the next couple weeks! Last weekend we climbed up this canyon for sunrise and found the entire top blooming with purple! Go check it out if you can! 
A post shared by @zandtrick on Mar 8, 2017 at 7:06am PST 
The small, nearby community of Borrego Springs more than doubled in size over the weekend — as an estimated 5,000 people poured in to the area to catch a glimpse of the nature phenomenon, according to the magazine.
As a result, the local sheriff was reportedly forced to close down several miles of road.
“I’ll go out on a limb and say it’ll last probably a week or two,” Sally Theriault, interpreter with the Anza-Borrego Desert State Park, told the San Diego Union-Tribune. 
Experts said that the spring bloom was ultimately caused by an extremely rainy fall and winter season, which came after a lengthy drought in California.
